qas.question: Why was the ability to play DVD-Video taken off of Windows Media Player?

answers.text: the cost of licensing the necessary decoders

qas.question: What does the Pro Pack do?

answers.text: upgrades the system to Windows 8 Pro

qas.question: Which main feature was removed in Windows 8?

plausible_answers.text: cost of licensing the necessary decoders

qas.question: Why was the ability to play BR-Video taken off of Windows Media Player?

plausible_answers.text: cost of licensing the necessary decoders

qas.question: Why was the ability to play DVD-Video taken off of Windows Picture Player?

plausible_answers.text: upgrades the system to Windows 8 Pro

qas.question: What doesn't the Pro Pack do?

plausible_answers.text: upgrades the system to Windows 8 Pro

qas.question: What does the Mod Pack do?
Which main feature was removed in Windows 9?

context: Several notable features have been removed in Windows 8, beginning with <a2_0>the <b7_0>traditional Start menu<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Support for playing DVD-Video was removed from Windows Media Player due to <a0_0>the <b3_0><b4_0>cost of licensing the necessary decoders<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> (especially for devices which do not include optical disc drives at all) and the prevalence of online streaming services. For the same reasons, Windows Media Center is not included by default on Windows 8, but Windows Media Center and DVD playback support can be purchased in the "Pro Pack" (which <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>upgrades the system to Windows 8 Pro<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>) or "Media Center Pack" add-on for Windows 8 Pro. As with prior versions, third-party DVD player software can still be used to enable DVD playback.
